title: Adjective Endings in Dutch
explanation:
Dutch adjectives change their form depending on the noun they describe. This is one of the trickier aspects of Dutch grammar, but there are clear rules.

Basic rule: Adjectives get an -E ending EXCEPT:
• Before HET-words that are singular and indefinite (een + het-word)
• When the adjective already ends in -en

Examples:
• de grote hond (the big dog) - DE word gets -E
• een grote hond (a big dog) - DE word gets -E  
• het grote huis (the big house) - HET word + definite gets -E
• een groot huis (a big house) - HET word + indefinite gets NO -E

This system helps distinguish between DE and HET words!
keyPoints: Adjectives usually add -E when describing nouns
Exception: HET-words with EEN (indefinite) get no -E
DE-words always get -E on their adjectives
This rule helps you identify DE vs HET words

examples.breakdown: DE-word with EEN: adjective still gets -E
HET-word with definite article: adjective gets -E
HET-word with EEN: adjective gets NO -E
HET-word with EEN: adjective gets NO -E
HET-word with definite article: adjective gets -E

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'een ___ huis' (big house)
exercises.explanation: Huis is a HET-word. With EEN (indefinite), the adjective gets no -E: een groot huis.
exercises.hint: Is 'huis' a DE or HET word? Is it definite or indefinite?

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'de ___ auto' (red car)
exercises.explanation: Auto is a DE-word. DE-words always get -E on their adjectives: de rode auto.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'het ___ boek' (new book)
exercises.explanation: Boek is a HET-word with definite article. Definite HET-words get -E: het nieuwe boek.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'een ___ kind' (small child)
exercises.explanation: Kind is a HET-word. With EEN (indefinite), the adjective gets no -E: een klein kind.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'de ___ vrouw' (beautiful woman)
exercises.explanation: Vrouw is a DE-word. DE-words always get -E on their adjectives: de mooie vrouw.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'een ___ man' (tall man)
exercises.explanation: Man is a DE-word. Even with EEN, DE-words get -E on their adjectives: een lange man.
exercises.hint: DE-words always get -E, even with EEN

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'het ___ water' (cold water)
exercises.explanation: Water is a HET-word with definite article. Definite HET-words get -E: het koude water.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'een ___ tafel' (wooden table)
exercises.explanation: Houten already ends in -en, so it doesn't change: een houten tafel.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'de ___ kinderen' (happy children)
exercises.explanation: Kinderen is plural. All plurals use DE, so adjectives get -E: de blije kinderen.
exercises.hint: Plurals use DE, so adjectives get -E

exercises.question: Choose the correct form: 'een ___ land' (small country)
exercises.explanation: Land is a HET-word. With EEN (indefinite), the adjective gets no -E: een klein land.

commonMistakes.explanation: HET-words with EEN don't get -E on the adjective
DE-words always get -E on their adjectives
DE-words always get -E, even with EEN

tips: Use this rule to test if a word is DE or HET: if 'een + adjective + noun' needs -E, it's a DE-word
Practice with color adjectives: een rood huis, de rode auto
Adjectives ending in -en (open, gebroken) never change
All plurals use DE, so adjectives always get -E
Common adjectives to practice: groot/klein, rood/blauw, nieuw/oud, mooi/lelijk
